title: Import, Manage, and Clean Data
contents:
The goal: To show my understanding of the learning objectives and provide evidence, I chose a data set about the nutrition facts of Starbucks’ drinks. I hope to use this data set to showcase what I have learned about R throughout the semester.
1. I can import data from a variety of sources.


drinks <- read_csv("~/STA 518/CourseProject/Personal-Website/_objectives/2021-12-09-numberone/
                   starbucks_drinkMenu_expanded.csv")




The above code chunk proves that I can import data from an external source, a .csv file. I downloaded this dataset onto my computer from Kaggle, then I uploaded the file into R Studio, then read it into my code. If this was an Excel file, I could have used drinks <- read_xlsx("~/STA 518/CourseProject/Personal-Website/ _objectives/2021-12-09-numberone/starbucks_drinkMenu_expanded.xlxs") instead. By showing that I can import both Excel and .csv files, that means that I can import data from a variety of sources.
2. I can write professional reports using R Markdown.



3. I can isolate information from a larger data source.
I am going to isolate the drinks that contain coffee or espresso. Coffee is usually my drink of choice, so I want to compare between the different types. This includes coffee, classic and signature espresso drinks, and frappuccinos.



4. I can combine information from multiple data sources.



5. I can restructure information to be in a “tidy” format.



6. I can transform information to be in a format better suited for specific tasks.

title: Write clear, efficient, and well-documented R programs.
